title: 105_s691
content: The "Public Land Management Participation Act of 1997" ensures public and congressional involvement in decisions regarding the use and management of public lands owned or controlled by the US government. It clarifies the roles of the public and Congress in the declaration of national monuments. The Antiquities Act is amended to include a new section requiring the Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture to involve the public and establish procedures for public input on national monument declarations. The Act also mandates compliance with federal land regulations before recommending any area for monument declaration. The Antiquities Act is amended to require the Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture to ensure compliance with federal land regulations, conduct mineral surveys, identify existing rights on federal lands, and report recommendations to the President for national monument declaration. The President must then inform Congress of these recommendations. The President must provide recommendations for national monument declarations, including maps and boundaries, within two years of receiving reports from the Secretary. Congress must pass an Act for the President's recommendation to become effective after the Public Land Management Participation Act. SEC. 4. CLARIFICATION OF PUBLIC AND CONGRESSIONAL ROLES IN WORLD HERITAGE SITE LISTING. Section 401 of the National Historic Preservation Act Amendments of 1980 is amended to include provisions for public involvement and procedures for designating areas not within the National Park System. The National Historic Preservation Act Amendments of 1980 now include procedures for public involvement in designating lands owned by the United States for inclusion on the World Heritage List. The Secretary of the Interior or Agriculture will review and make recommendations to the President, who will then inform Congress of his recommendations. The President must advise Congress within two years of receiving a report from the Secretary regarding the designation of US-owned lands for the World Heritage List. Any recommendation for inclusion on the list of World Heritage in Danger must be accompanied by a report to Congress by the Secretary of the Interior or Agriculture. The Secretary of the Interior and Agriculture must submit an annual report on each World Heritage Site in the US to Congress, detailing money spent, federal hours dedicated to site management, and contributions from nongovernmental organizations. The annual report on each US World Heritage Site must include details on money spent, federal hours dedicated to site management, contributions from nongovernmental organizations, and a summary of complaints received by the Secretary related to site management. SEC. 5. CLARIFICATION OF PUBLIC AND CONGRESSIONAL ROLES IN THE DESIGNATION OF UNITED NATIONS BIOSPHERE RESERVES. Title IV of the National Historic Preservation Act Amendments of 1980 prohibits Federal officials from nominating lands in the United States for designation as a Biosphere Reserve under the Man and Biosphere Program of UNESCO without specific authorization from Congress. The Secretary of the Interior and Agriculture must involve the public and establish procedures for public input, including hearings when necessary. The Secretary of the Interior or Agriculture must involve the public in the designation of lands as Biosphere Reserves under the Man and Biosphere Program. Recommendations are made to the President, who then informs Congress within two years. After the effective date of the Public Land Participation Management Act, a recommendation of the President for declaration of a Biosphere Reserve shall become effective only if so provided by an Act of Congress. The Secretary of State must submit an annual report on each Biosphere Reserve within the United States to specific committees in Congress, detailing money spent, federal hours dedicated, and contributions from nongovernmental organizations. The curr_chunk discusses the requirement for organizations to contribute to the management of the reserve and the need for a summary of complaints related to reserve management.
